Wie oft alsdann der Buddha, der Meister, ... einen Schritt setzte, ebenso oft brüllte diese Erde/Erdgöttin.
As often then as the Buddha, the Master, made a step, equally as often the earth(goddess) roared.

Anytime the Buddha, the teacher, (decorated) and adorned with the 32 marks [of the great man] and the 80 gentle jewels, took a step, as if he were a … mountain, just as many times the earth roared and resounded as if out of joy, and just as many times rays spread from the crown of his head and from his mouth towards all ten cardinal points, [which] blinded gods and men, as it were.

and humans in all 10 regions of the world. When they saw this, the senses of gods [and] men were attracted as it were. Therefore, the great kings, starting with Prasenajit, and

Infolgedessen versammelten sich fern von [ihren] Ländern, eiligst [und] ohne [irgendwelche] Bemühung die großen Könige, Prasenajit usw., [und] die Laienkönige, Bimbisara usw., Gegend für Gegend aus [ihren] Ländern, je von ihren zehn Millionen von Ministern [und] Leuten des Landes umgeben.

Consequently, there gathered, hurriedly [and] without [much] effort, far from [their] countries, the great kings, Prasenajit etc. [and] the lay kings, Bimbisara etc., area by area from [their] countries, each surrounded by their ten millions of ministers [and] people of the country.
the lay kings, starting with Bimbisāra, area by area from [their] lands, surrounded by 10 million ministers [and] noblemen, at (the marvel) of the god of gods, the Buddha,

they gathered, even going far from [their] countries, hurriedly [and] without effort. Thus also went Anāthapiṇḍika, Ugra, Luhasudatta, to start with, who already had obtained a rank, the lay brother, house(holders,)
Koṭīśvaras, rich ones, caravan leaders, the queens, surrounded by goddesslike women, Kṣemā, Mālikā, etc., the lay sisters, Viśākhā, Sujātā, etc.

[Furthermore] the six Tīrtha-teachers went, Puraṇa, Maskari, etc., surrounded by [their] Kāpālikas, Ulūkas, Tāpasas, Nirgranthas [and] Parivrājakas (wandering monks) respectively, (and other countless)
people of the land. Likewise the Rūpadhātu-gods went, starting from the five Śuddhāvasās; Śubhakṛtsna, Ābhāsvara, Brahmaloka, etc.,
to see the marvel of the god of gods, the Buddha. The four kings of the Kāmadhātu [world] (went), Indra (with) Suyāma, Saṃtuṣita, Su(nirmāṇarati), each
surrounded by [their] own divine crowd, letting rain divine flowers, clothes, jewels [and] heavenly golden jewelry; [Furthermore], the Gandharvas went by the hundreds, Citra, Citrāṅgata, Timburu etc.

Götter [und] Menschen sehen sich gegenseitig.
Gods [and] humans saw each other.
other. The earth all around was covered with flowers; it was lovely as the heavenly [earth]. 1. The god Māra saw this. Excited he then fetched [his] bow of flowers, trusting in the arrow of passion.
Erregt holte er [scil. der Gott Māra] damals seinen Blumenbogen im Vertrauen auf den Pfeil der Leidenschaft.
Excited, he [i.e. the god Māra], at that time, fetched his bow of flowers, trusting in the arrow of passion.
(Die Erde) war (ringsum(?)) mit Blumen bedeckt, sie war lieblich wie die himmlische [Erde].
(The earth) was covered with flowers (all around(?)), it was lovely like the heavenly [earth].

He went to exactly this (place), [but] being (confused) this one did not recognize the direction for himself, wherefore (he did not find) the arrow. With joy the gods were almost overwhelmed. But he alone (glowed)
Er [scil. Māra] ging (zu) eben der (Stelle, [aber] verwirrt) geworden, erkannte er für sich nicht die Richtung, wodurch (er) den Pfeil (nicht fand).
He [i.e. Māra] went (to) the very same (place, [but]) having become (confused), he did not recognize the direction for himself, wherefore (he did not find) the arrow.

260 suggests to supplement mäṃtne y(etu wsāṣi) ṣul tāṣ “as if he were (a decorated) mountain (of gold)”.
This appears to be the end of a second verse of a tune of 4x14 syllables, rhythm 7/7.
260 would prefer the names to be rendered as Lūhasudatta, Pūraṇa, Maskarin and Timbura respectively.
260 suggests to supplement kucāne campär (mā osāt) “wherefore the arrow (did not hit him)”.
